column2: Chhatrapati Sambhajinagar Civic Body Imposes Late Payment Charges On Newly Recorded Properties; Residents Upset
column5: Chhatrapati Sambhajinagar: People are upset as many cases of the civic body slapping late fee payment charges while calculating the property tax on newly recorded properties have emerged in Chhatrapati Sambhajinagar city.Though the Chhatrapati Sambhajinagar Municipal Corporation (CSMC) failed to bring these properties under the tax regime on its own, when property holders themselves approached the civic body (to enter the tax net), they were levied late payment charges.Prashant Washikar, one of the affected taxpayers, said his property came on record during the current fiscal year, but he was made to pay late payment charges for the previous two financial years. "The civic authorities did not approach us to get us in the tax net when our housing society received the completion certificate around two and a half years ago. We took voluntary measures so that proper property tax is charged. In such cases, it is unjust to levy late payment charges on us," he said.The CSMC imposes a 2% late payment charge per month if the property tax is not paid for the first half before June 30 and before Dec 31 for the second half of the financial year. The monthly late payment charges have a compounding effect on the original tax amount. Many people whose properties were newly recorded are reeling under the financial burden.Earlier, the municipal limits had a large number of unregistered properties, even if property holders were occupying them for a considerable period. The CSMC announced 65% more tax if a property was recorded after the end of the last fiscal year. The decision, which was dubbed controversial and arbitrary by citizens, resulted in many citizens ensuring their property gets recorded with the civic body.Shiv Sena (UBT) politician and former standing committee chairman of CSMC, Raju Vaidya, said the sole rule of the administrator has paved the way for anarchy. "The date of the property coming on record should be considered while imposing late payment charges. The CSMC itself gives the completion certificate and henceforth should become proactive in charging the property tax instead of making citizens run from pillar to post to come under the tax net," he said.When contacted, CSMC authorities said late payment charges are applied as per established rules. "In many cases, we bring new properties under the tax net immediately after citizens start residing in them. In some cases, alert citizens ensure the completion of property tax-related formalities. Citizens with tax-related complaints are requested to attend the fortnightly grievance redressal programme," a senior CSMC official said.Get the latest lifestyle updates on Times of India, along with Navratri Wishes, Eid Messages and quotes !

column2: 'Whatsapp Messages And Google Maps Exposed Rs 250 Crore Tax Evasion': Finance Minister Sitharaman In Lok Sabha
column5: WhatsApp Messages and Google Maps exposed Rs 250 crore tax evasion The Union Finance Minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, recently defended the provisions of the new Income Tax Bill, 2025 in Parliament, highlighting the importance of enhanced digital surveillance in uncovering financial fraud. During her address, she revealed that WhatsApp messages and Google Maps history had played a crucial role in detecting unaccounted wealth linked to crypto assets. The finance minister emphasised that modern technology is essential in curbing tax evasion and ensuring financial transparency. This comes as the government aims to replace the Income Tax Act of 1961, which has been in place for over six decades, with a more modern and simplified tax framework.How WhatsApp messages and Google Maps exposed Rs 250 crore tax evasionThe finance minister outlined multiple cases where digital surveillance helped uncover substantial amounts of hidden wealth. Some of the key revelations include:Use of WhatsApp messages: Authorities detected Rs 200 crore of unaccounted money linked to crypto transactions through encrypted chats.Google Maps history analysis: Investigators traced frequent visits to hidden cash storage locations, enabling successful raids.Instagram and social media monitoring: Suspect 'benami' property ownership was identified by analyzing social media activity and extravagant lifestyle indicators.Email and business software audits: Tax evasion cases were unearthed by tracking undisclosed transactions hidden in company databases and communication platforms.What is the Income Tax Bill, 2025Introduced in the Lok Sabha on February 13, 2025, the new bill aims to overhaul the outdated Income Tax Act of 1961 by adapting to evolving economic landscapes and digital advancements. The key objectives of the new tax bill include:Modernization of direct taxation: Aligning tax laws with technological advancements and new economic realities.Enhanced surveillance on digital transactions: Addressing tax evasion through digital footprints, including communication records.Simplification of tax structures: Reducing ambiguities and making tax compliance easier for individuals and businesses.Stronger provisions against financial fraud: Enabling authorities to track and investigate unaccounted wealth more efficiently.New powers granted to tax authoritiesUnder the new Income Tax Bill, 2025, tax officials will have expanded authority to:Access communication platforms like WhatsApp, Telegram, and email to investigate tax fraud.Examine business software and cloud storage used for financial transactions.Monitor cryptocurrency transactions to prevent tax evasion in digital assets.Leverage AI-based forensic tools to detect suspicious financial activities.Impact on individuals and businessesThe introduction of this bill has far-reaching implications for taxpayers:For individuals: Increased scrutiny of digital transactions means individuals must ensure complete transparency in their financial dealings. Those engaged in crypto trading, offshore accounts, or high-value transactions could face stricter monitoring.For businesses: Organizations must maintain clear digital records of financial transactions. The bill also places additional compliance requirements on firms using business software and digital communication tools.For digital platforms: Tech companies may be required to store and provide access to encrypted data when requested by authorities.Challenges and concernsWhile the government argues that the new bill enhances financial transparency, it has also raised concerns regarding:Privacy issues: Granting tax authorities access to private digital communications could lead to data privacy and civil liberty concerns.Implementation challenges: Enforcing these new measures may require advanced technological infrastructure and training for tax officials.Possible misuse of authority: Critics fear that the broader investigative powers could be misused for political or personal gains.Also read | Genshin Impact Codes | Fruit Battlegrounds Codes | Blox Fruits Codes
column6: During her address, she revealed that WhatsApp messages and Google Maps history had played a crucial role in detecting unaccounted wealth linked to crypto assets. The finance minister emphasised that modern technology is essential in curbing tax evasion and ensuring financial transparency.

column2: Gst Administration Urges Taxpayers To Use Amnesty Scheme To Settle Pending Tax Before March End
column5: Mumbai: The GST administration encourages taxpayers to utilise the Amnesty Scheme for settling their pending tax obligations before March ends. This scheme focuses on resolving outstanding GST disputes from Financial Years 2017-2020. Under this initiative, taxpayers can clear their dues by paying only the primary tax amount, whilst receiving complete exemption from penalties and interest charges, provided they comply with the scheme's stipulations. The scheme's provisions also extend to instances where proper officers have issued formal orders.
